title: Dynamic Planning for Link Discovery
segmentation: Hello everyone, good afternoon and welcome to the session.
My name is Clancy Joella, armpits student from the University of Leipzig and I'm here to present to you dynamic planning for link discovery.
Before I begin, I would like to give you an overview of what you're going to see today.
So first I'm going to talk about the motivation behind our work.
Then I'm going to give you details regarding our approach for dynamic planning.
After that, I'm going to talk about the valuation such as experimental setup and results.
And finally, I'm going to conclude and talk about future work.
So.
To begin.
Death over.

For the past few years, technological progress in network infrastructure and hardware development has led to an increased collection of data from diverse resources such as sparkle endpoints, industrial plans, Internet of Things, and since with the uptake of web semantic technologies, this data is very easy to be transformed into RDF.
And since this data is available in RDF, that means.

But we have to follow the 4th link data principle, which says we have to link things, which is basically the essence of link discovering more formally, the goal of Link discovery is to find a set of resources S&T, given two sets, S&T capital of resources in a relationship R that satisfy this relation.
This set of links we call it M or mapping.
Now computing this.
A computing M directly might be difficult.

Another result declarative link discovery frameworks compute and prime, which consists of the set of links, SMT whose similarity measure Sigma is above or equal to threshold Theta and how they do that.
They're using specification.
Now you might wonder what is a link specification.
So I think the specification basically describes the conditions under which this relationship are holds.
It consists of similarity measures, which is basically function M that Maps S * T to the interval 0 to one and also specification operator such as intersection union difference.
And here is an example of a link specification.
This link specification, we call it complex becausw.
It consists of two other link specification who are combined together using an operator.
In this case we have intersection.
The bottom link specification.
We call it left child and the top we call it right child.
And both of the Children Link specification are called Atomic Link specification because they only consist of similarity measure and a threshold.
Now go through.
The challenges regarding discovering the first challenge is accuracy.
We want to be able to retrieve correct links and based on the related work, there's been a lot of approaches included but not limited to genetic programming and refinement operators.
Now the second challenge that we're also tackling in this work is time efficiency.
We don't only want a correct links, but we want them fast and we want to make sure our approaches are able to scale.
So so far.

Regarding regarding time efficiency, there is being proposed in related work algorithms for planning, such as Halios, who its uses runtime approximation functions to it to estimate the runtime of similarity atomic similarity measures.
But as far as we know the best or knowledge is never been a planning algorithm that exploits a global knowledge regarding the link specification.
So here today I am to present you the first dynamic planning approach for link discovery dump dump Condor.

The intuition behind our work is that the execution ending itself might be able to provide more information about the runtimes of link specification than the planner itself, since it has executed some part of it.

The initial plan over Link specification by information received from a feedback loop between the planner and execution engine.
Also, in this approach, we make sure that duplicated steps are executed once and we consider dependencies between the steps of the plan.

Before I go into more details regarding corner, I would like to show you a an idea of how the workflow in dynamic execution of Link specification works.

The link specification is given to every writer, and the Rewriter receives the link specification.
I'm not going to talk about the rewriter in in this work because it's beyond the scope.
So once the writer has reshaped the link specification, it gives it to the planner.
The planner creates an initial plan, then it gives us the execution engine.
The execution ending itself executes a part of the link specification.
It takes this information from the runtimes, sends it back to the planner, and a planner comes up with the next more improved plan.
And this continues until there is no more steps of the link specification that has not been executed and at the end we get the set of links are mapping.
